articles.title: About Scout
articles.contents:
Scout Leonard is a recent graduate of the Masters of Environmental Data Science program at the Bren School at the University of California Santa Barbara. Currently, she is a fellow with the Stanford University Data Science for Social Good Program. Scout is passionate about data visualization and open, reproducible data science.



Scout graduated from Harvard College in 2018 with her BA in Integrative Biology and minor in Energy and the Environment. During college, Scout led consulting projects for nonprofits such as the Planetary Health Alliance as a project leader in the Harvard College Conservation Society. She also conducted research with Professor Brian Farrell on island endemism and plant phylogenetics.



Supported by the Weissman Fellowship, Scout created apiary management systems for forest-edge hives in Kibale National Forest, Uganda, with the Kasiisi Project. These “beehive-fences” have conservation, economic, and social benefits, even to this day; they reduce human-elephant conflict and provide income to farmers. This project inspired Scout’s interest in multidisciplinary sustainability projects, particularly those that emphasize environmental justice.



As such, Scout has spent the last 3 years working on urban food systems in Oakland, California with No Kid Hungry and FoodCorps. She oversaw food system programs by managing procurement, participation, and waste data across the city; Scout believes that every person has the right to nutritious food, and her work expanded access to healthy school meals for Oakland. Using data science, Scout hopes to transform human-environmental systems to be more sustainable and equitable.

Work Experience
Share Our Strength: No Kid Hungry Campaign | Oakland Unified School District Breakfast After the Bell Specialist  | Oakland, California. | 2019-2020.
Program assessment and implementation across 50 OUSD schools for No Kid Hungry’s Breakfast After the Bell, which strategically ensures more free-and-reduced-lunch-eligible students have access to breakfast
Maintained grant compliance, developed qualitative and quantitative program measures, wrote analytic reports for funders on behalf of 25 schools which received funding for Breakfast After the Bell programming
Creative problem solving and support around various programmatic challenges at multiple levels, relying especially on building interpersonal relationships with stakeholders at the school and district level and strong communication skills
The Periodic Table | Bartender | Emeryville, California. | 2019-2020.
Familiarized myself with history, science, brewing operations, and cultural significance of more than 30 sake varieties, as well as Japanese spirits and California craft beer
Provided friendly, professional, and knowledgeable customer service to bar patrons
Managed and served the bar independently; carried out opening and closing procedures, as well as problem-solving technological, culinary, and customer service challenges

FoodCorps | AmeriCorps Service Member | Oakland, California. | 2018-2019.
Completed 1700 hours of service in 2 school communities as the sites’ food and garden educator, serving students, their families, teachers, cafeteria staff, and administrators in fostering a schoolwide culture of health
Developed culturally-relevant, hands-on health curriculum to foster healthy habits, reinforce science standards, and increase accessibility to nutritious foods and the outdoors; taught PK-5th grade students
Convened diverse stakeholders to build strategic partnerships in the community to mobilize change in school gardens and cafeterias; generated student choice in cafeteria culture by creating and implementing Socratic seminars
Competitively chosen for National Alumni Council to continue supporting FoodCorps alumni in connecting with professions and professionals which support youth hunger-fighting initiatives, school food, policy, and agriculture

Atlantic White Shark Conservancy | Summer Fellow | Chatham, Massachusetts. | Summer 2018.
Secured grant funding for an added internship position through the Harvard Center for Public Interest Careers
Led new partnerships with the Cape Cod Fishermen’s Alliance, Northwest Atlantic Seal Research Consortium, and CARE for the Cape and Islands to communicate holistic messaging about the Cape’s environment and history
Communicated ongoing Great White Shark population research and safety information, as well as other science with accessible exhibits designed using Adobe and Microsoft programs, as well as spoken presentations

Adams House, Harvard University | Assistant to the Building Manager | Cambridge, Massachusetts. | 2015-2018.
Greeted dormitory residents and community with warmth and helpfulness as they entered the building and retrieved their mail; completed administrative tasks for dormitory building operations with efficiency and organization
Maintained safe, secure entry procedures to ensure the safety of the dormitory building and resident community
Provided excellent and efficient service; logged arrived mail and sent email reminders for pick-up, problem-solved with Harvard building maintenance staff around infrastructural and operational events for Adams House students

Harvard College Conservation Society | Project Leader | Cambridge, Massachusetts. | 2017-2018.
Coordinated with conservation education team at the Kasiisi Project in Uganda to establish curriculum goals
Managed undergraduate team in developing educational tools for the Kasiisi Project’s conservation education program; delegated core responsibilities; supported team members in understanding goals and vision of the project
Implemented team-building activities to foster an inclusive, community space where team members could bring their whole selves while working on our project

The Kasiisi Project | Beekeeping and Conservation Intern | Fort Portal, Uganda. | Summer 2017.
Built close relationships with local farmers and beekeepers to develop apiary management best practices and systems which improved hive productivity (now harvesting and selling honey)
Installed Broodminder hive monitoring devices and trained local beekeepers to do the same and collect data from the devices. Used in global honeybee citizen science and to understand the role of apiaries in conserving elephants
Planned educational materials and activities and taught regional elementary school students about honeybees, their biology, beekeeping, and other environmental topics; collaborated with local educators to teach appropriate content

Harvard University Farrell Lab | Undergraduate Researcher | Cambridge, Massachusetts. | 2016-2018.
Learned and independently executed various lab techniques in beetle and plant genomics (DNA amplification, PCR, sequencing), as well as the programs used to understand and analyze genomic data, such as R and Geneius
Researched existing, relevant academic work within Aristolochia plant genomics and applied techniques to my own project using Aristolochia samples from Hispaniola
Participated in lab discussions and presented in group meetings with graduate student researchers

Harvard University Museum of Natural History | Undergraduate Research Assistant | Cambridge, Massachusetts. | 2015-2016.
Collaborated with museum team to develop vision for “What’s in a Name?” exhibit and online resources
Independently researched biological and scientific information regarding binomial nomenclature and that of specific species; using this research, wrote science communication pieces and compiled relevant images for museum patrons

South Shore YMCA Camps Burgess and Hayward | Counselor in Training, Junior Counselor, and Counselor | Sandwich, Massachusetts. | 2013-2015.
Cultivated a space of inclusion, joy, and courage for girls ages 8-15 by emphasizing group norms and practices and
celebrating uniqueness of individual campers, most of whom were away from home for the first time

            Hi and welcome!
            I am a Data Analyst II in Oakland Unified School District’s
            (OUSD) Research, Assessment, and Data
            department. In my role, I support the District’s
            Community Schools and Student Services (CSSS) Department.
            Community Schools are full service sites that support
            students with an integrated approach to academics, public
            health, social services, and community development. I always
            want my work to contribute toward projects that support an
            equitable, joyful, and sustainable future, and so CSSS is a
            meaningful place to be.
            I am a recent graduate of the Masters of Environmental Data
            Science program at the Bren School at the
            University of California Santa Barbara. I also recently
            concluded my fellowship with Stanford University’s Data Science
            for Social Good Program. My team at Stanford
